Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: A family member has a new job and has shared some initial excitement about it with their relatives.
Expectation2: Deliver packages on time and to the correct address
Situation2: A package arrives slightly later than expected, but still within the same day
Story: I glanced at my phone as I parked the delivery van, a message from my granddaughter lighting up the screen. She’d just started her new job and wanted to share her first-day excitement with me. My daughter had already texted, “Don’t forget to call her tonight—she’s been waiting to tell you everything!” I smiled, feeling the warmth of being needed, but my gaze shifted to the back of the van where a package sat, addressed to a customer who’d been tracking it all day. It was running a bit late, though still within the promised window, and I knew the company expected me to deliver every parcel promptly and without error. My supervisor had reminded us just this morning: “No delays, no mistakes.” I felt the tug of both worlds—my family expecting my attention and support, my job demanding my focus and punctuality. My heart ached at the thought of missing my granddaughter’s call, but my hands tightened on the steering wheel, knowing the customer was waiting too. I sat there, torn, the weight of both roles pressing in as I tried to decide which expectation to meet first.
